title-group.article-title: When You Don’t Quite Get What You Want
title-group.subtitle: Psychological and Interpersonal Consequences of Claiming Inclusion

author-notes.corresp: Wendy de Waal-Andrews, Department of Social Psychology, Tilburg University, Warandelaan 2, 5037 AB Tilburg, Netherlands Email: W.G.deWaal-Andrews@uvt.nl

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 by the Society for Personality and Social Psychology, Inc
permissions.copyright-holder: Society for Personality and Social Psychology, Inc.

abstract.p: People’s success or failure to gain inclusion in groups may result from their own actions or the actions of others. Two studies compared the personal and interpersonal consequences of inclusion and exclusion when they resulted from these two processes. People’s own failure to “claim” inclusion in a computerized ballgame was equally detrimental for fundamental needs and made people equally unlikely to behave prosocially to group members, as being denied inclusion by others. In contrast, the beneficial effects of inclusion depended on the process with which it was obtained, and meta-perceptions of warmth mediated these differences; people who succeeded to claim inclusion thought their interaction partners liked them less than people who were granted inclusion, and as a result, their fundamental needs were satisfied less, and they behaved less prosocially.

body.p: Humans are social beings who seek inclusion (Baumeister & Leary, 1995) and react immediately and intensely to signs of exclusion or ostracism (K. D. Williams, 2007, 2009). Compared with inclusion, exclusion threatens people’s fundamental needs, decreases their mood (Blackhart, Nelson, Knowles, & Baumeister, 2009; Gerber & Wheeler, 2009), and impairs self-regulation (DeWall & Baumeister, 2006). Exclusion also makes people feel colder than inclusion (Zhong & Leonardelli, 2008) and causes their brains to register higher levels of pain (Eisenberger, Lieberman, & Williams, 2003). In short, people dislike exclusion and like inclusion.

In this article, we take a closer look at people’s experience of inclusion and exclusion when they result mostly from their own actions or mostly from other people’s actions. More specifically, we assess whether people’s psychological and behavioral reaction to inclusion or exclusion differs depending on the primary source of the actions leading to it. Moreover, we investigate why this may be the case.

sec.title: Distinguishing End-States and Processes
sec.p: What do we mean by inclusion and exclusion? To answer this question, we argue first that it is important to distinguish between the end-state and the processes leading to it. As end-states, inclusion and exclusion refer to people’s level of connectedness with others. Thus, an included person is part of social bonds or relationships, whereas an excluded person is not part of social bonds or relationships and thus isolated (Leary, 2005). More importantly, we argue that there are two important processes that lead to these two states. Although, generally, both will to some extent be a cause of inclusion or exclusion, we argue that either of these processes may be the predominant cause in a given situation.

At the one extreme, we argue, people may end up included or excluded primarily as a result of other people’s actions. For example, people may or may not be asked for their opinion, be kept in the loop of information, be asked to join a work group, or be invited to a birthday party. Although people may exert some effort to secure inclusion in these examples, ultimately others’ decision on whether to include them determines whether this will happen. Research has found that the actions causing inclusion or exclusion may range from simply involving some individuals in activities and ignoring others (Farina & Ring, 1965; Lott, 2002), to more explicitly inviting some individuals to join a group and refusing others to do so (Farina & Felner, 1973). Sometimes, exclusion may even be harshly enforced by collectively humiliating some individuals (Schuster, 1996) or by giving them the silent treatment (Gruter, 1986). Key in all these examples is that other people’s actions play an instrumental role in causing a target’s state of inclusion or exclusion. That is, people end up included or excluded primarily because other people’s actions cause their inclusion or other people’s actions cause their exclusion.

At the other extreme, we argue, inclusion or exclusion may result primarily from people’s own actions. For example, joining some groups requires people to demonstrate their suitability (e.g., provide credentials, demonstrate skills) or take part in initiation rituals such as hazing (Lodewijkx & Syroit, 1997, 2001). Inclusion may also depend on meeting more implicit requirements, and people are highly sensitive to cues of such implicit norms. For example, people often conform to other people’s opinions (Cialdini & Trost, 1998), even when those others hold incorrect judgments (K. D. Williams, Cheung, & Choi, 2000). They also buy products and brands that other people buy as well (Escalas & Bettman, 2005; Leibenstein, 1950) to ensure that they fit in. Indeed, people who are successful at meeting such explicit or implicit membership requirements end up included, whereas people who fail to do so end up excluded. In other words, inclusion or exclusion primarily results from people’s own success or failure to do what is necessary to ensure inclusion. That is, people end up included or excluded primarily because their own actions cause inclusion or their own actions cause exclusion.

To our knowledge, we are the first to explicitly focus on these two different antecedents of inclusion and exclusion. Existing experimental research often focuses on inclusion and exclusion that result predominantly from the actions of others. For example, people are or are not involved or excluded by others in work tasks (Nezlek, Kowalski, Leary, Blevins, & Holgate, 1997), group discussions (Gardner, Pickett, & Brewer, 2000), or a game of ball toss (K. D. Williams et al., 2000). Moreover, some research uses paradigms that place more emphasis on peoples’ own actions. For example, in the future-alone paradigm, excluded participants are told that they “are the type who will end up alone later in life” (Twenge, Baumeister, Tice, & Stucke, 2001, p. 1060; Van Beest & Williams, 2011). However, there is no prior research that has compared these antecedents in a single paradigm.

Distinguishing between the end-states of inclusion and exclusion and the processes leading to them is important for understanding the psychological and behavioral consequences of inclusion and exclusion, under which conditions they occur, and why. A substantive body of research has found that, compared with social inclusion, social exclusion makes people feel worse and threatens their fundamental needs for belongingness, self-esteem, control, and meaningful existence (Blackhart et al., 2009; Gerber & Wheeler, 2009). However, it remains unclear whether the observed effects are generally the result of the satisfaction of inclusion, the distress of exclusion, or both (Blackhart et al., 2009; Gerber & Wheeler, 2009). Moreover, behavioral reactions to exclusion are as diverse as acts of aggression (Warburton, Williams, & Cairns, 2006), seeking new connections (Maner, DeWall, Baumeister, & Schaller, 2007) and ingratiation (Romero-Canyas et al., 2010), and research has only begun to disentangle the situational conditions and individual differences that underlie these differences. Distinguishing between different sources of inclusion and exclusion may provide a useful framework in which to interpret the existing findings and understand why they occur.

sec.title: Hypotheses
sec.p: So will people react differently if their inclusionary status is predominantly the result of their own actions or the actions of others? For the state of exclusion, we argue they will not, at least not immediately. Here, we draw on prior theorizing that people’s immediate reaction to exclusion is undifferentiated and negative, with a fundamental underlying argument that human beings are social animals who are predisposed to over-detect cues signaling an exclusion threat (Baumeister & Leary, 1995; Van Beest, Williams, & Van Dijk, 2011; K. D. Williams, 2009). Given the potential threat of exclusion to survival, such a “reflexive” (K. D. Williams, 2009) initial reaction to exclusion makes sense: How one ended up excluded does not matter at this stage. All that matters is that one is alone and, thus, potentially in danger. Providing evidence for this assertion, research has found that people who are excluded experience immediate psychological pain (Eisenberger et al., 2003) no matter who (the Ku Klux Klan: Gonsalkorale & Williams, 2007; strangers: K. D. Williams et al., 2000; a computer: Zadro, Williams, & Richardson, 2004) or how many people (Chernyak & Zayas, 2010) reject you, whether doing so was costly or not (Van Beest & Williams, 2006), or whether they had a choice (following a script or not: Zadro et al., 2004). We assert that, in addition, this will be the case no matter whether exclusion is based on one’s own actions or on the actions of others.

The state of inclusion, however, does not represent acute danger. As a result, rather than reacting in a reflexive and undifferentiated manner, people should be ready to appreciate differences in how they got included right from the start. As a result, we argue that their reactions to inclusion will differ if it results from their own actions or those of others. Why may this be the case? Satisfying the need to belong may require having both ongoing interactions with a person and having a relationship marked by concern and caring (Baumeister & Leary, 1995). In support of this view, studies of romantic relationships have found that inclusion fails to be satisfying when affective feelings are unrequited (Baumeister, Wotman, & Stillwell, 1993) or relationships lack mutual concern (Clark & Mills, 1979).

How may reactions to claimed and granted inclusion then differ? Claiming and being granted inclusion are equally viable ways of securing ongoing interactions. After all, how one attains inclusion does not affect the frequency with which one interacts. However, when one is granted inclusion, this may be perceived as a sign that one is appreciated, possibly even cared about, by interaction partners, whereas it seems difficult to attribute such feelings to interaction partners when inclusion is claimed for oneself.

Prior research on social inclusion and exclusion provides some support for this view. For example, although prior research on ostracism generally finds that inclusion is not more or less moderated by cross-cutting variables than exclusion, there is one often overlooked exception. Zadro and colleagues (2004) studied whether it mattered if inclusion or exclusion was allegedly based on people’s own decision to toss or not toss a ball to the participant, or whether they were simply following a script. This difference did not impact people’s immediate evaluation of exclusion, but it did impact people’s immediate evaluation of inclusion. When coplayers allegedly chose whom to toss the ball to, inclusion was more satisfying than when they followed a script (Zadro et al., 2004). Although the study did not explicitly assess this, it seems possible that participants interpreted the self-determined choice of their interaction partners to include them in the game, to reflect at least some level of concern for their well-being. In line with this reasoning, we contend that to offer maximum psychological benefit, inclusion needs to be granted by others rather than claimed for oneself.

sec.title: Study 1
sec.p: Cyberball (K. D. Williams et al., 2000) is a powerful paradigm for manipulating inclusion in or exclusion from a group. In its classic form, it can be interpreted as a game of giving and receiving inclusion. Participants are led to believe they are playing a virtual ballgame with two or three others. Players determine to whom they will throw the ball by clicking one of the schematic figures on the screen. Thus, participants’ inclusion or exclusion in the game allegedly results from other players’ willingness to throw them the ball. In reality, participants are not playing with other people, but the computer determines other players’ ball throws. In the typical inclusion condition, participants receive the ball about as often as other players, whereas excluded participants receive only a couple of throws. In other words, the computer determines the outcome of classic cyberball, but participants are led to believe that their inclusion or exclusion in the game results from the behavior of the other players.

A simple change to the instructions and procedure of the game, but not to its outcome, allowed us to compare the consequences of inclusion and exclusion when they result from other players’ behavior and when they result largely from participants’ own behavior. In the altered version, termed claimball for the current purpose, participants “claimed” the ball by being the first to click on the figure on the screen of the player who had the ball.1 In other words, included participants succeeded to claim the ball from other players and excluded ones failed to do so. To ensure the outcomes mirrored those of the classic cyberball game, the game was rigged such that participants in the inclusion condition managed to claim the ball as often as the other players, whereas participants in the exclusion condition only managed to get a couple of throws. In other words, the outcomes of claimball mirror those of classic cyberball. However, in claimball, participants are led to believe that their inclusion or exclusion in the game results largely from their own behavior, whereas in classic cyberball it allegedly results from the behavior of the other players.

In line with earlier research using the cyberball paradigm (e.g., Van Beest & Williams, 2006; Zadro et al., 2004), we assessed the effects of inclusion and exclusion on people’s fundamental needs for belonging, self-esteem, meaningful existence, and control. We predicted that exclusion from claimball would have an equally negative impact on these fundamental needs as exclusion from classic cyberball. Moreover, we predicted that inclusion in claimball would not satisfy people’s fundamental needs to the same extent as inclusion in classic cyberball.

sec.title: Participants and procedure
sec.p: Psychology undergraduates at Tilburg University (N = 136) were randomly assigned to a 2 (game experience: inclusion, exclusion) × 2 (game type: claimball, classic cyberball) between-subject design. Four participants failed to complete the measures, leaving 132 participants (84.1% female) ranging in age from 18 to 35 (M = 19.84, SD = 2.37).

In a private cubicle, participants received detailed instructions of the ballgame, which was presented as a mental visualization exercise (K. D. Williams et al., 2000). Each game had three players and was set to run a total number of 30 ball tosses. The participant received about 10 (i.e., 1/3) ball tosses in the inclusion condition or 2 in the exclusion condition. The game was followed by an assessment of its impact, manipulation checks, and a full debrief.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: As is customary in research using the cyberball paradigm, need satisfaction was measured with a composite of four fundamental needs (K. D. Williams, 2009). Participants rated, respectively, the level of belonging (e.g., “I felt as one with the other players”), control (e.g., “I felt that I was in control of the game”), self-esteem (e.g., “Playing the game made me feel insecure” [reverse scored]), and meaningful existence (e.g., “I thought my participation in the game was useful”) that they experienced during the game. The 20-item scale (Van Beest & Williams, 2006; α = .95) featured 5 items per need rated on a 7-point bipolar scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 7 (very much).

To check whether participants correctly perceived the game experience, we asked, “What percentage of the throws did you receive?” Their understanding of the game type was assessed with a forced choice question: “How was the game played?” (I had to click to throw the ball/I had to click to claim the ball). Participants also rated their engagement in the game (M = 2.05, SD = 1.08, α = .84) on three items (i.e., “The game was exciting/challenging/engrossing”) on a 7-point bipolar scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 7 (very much).

sec.title: Manipulation checks
sec.p: A 2 (game experience) × 2 (game type) ANOVA on the manipulation check revealed that included participants (M = 32.26, SD = 11.84) recalled receiving a larger proportion of the ball tosses than excluded participants (M = 7.59, SD = 8.49), F(1, 127) = 182.81, p < .001, η2 = .57. Moreover, all participants (100%) correctly stated whether they had to click to throw the ball or to claim the ball. No other differences were significant.

sec.title: Engagement
sec.p: Running the Game experience × Game type ANOVA on the engagement composite revealed only a main effect of game type, F(1, 128) = 4.08, p = .045, η2 = .031, such that engagement was higher in claimball (M = 2.23, SD = 1.20) than in classic cyberball (M = 1.86, SD = 0.91), and a main effect of game condition, F(1, 128) = 6.73, p = .011, η2 = .050, such that engagement was higher when people were included (M = 2.28, SD = 1.15) than when they were excluded (M = 1.81, SD = 0.95).

sec.title: Need satisfaction
sec.p: A 2 (game experience) × 2 (game type) ANOVA on the need satisfaction composite yielded a main effect of game experience, F(1, 128) = 209.77, p < .001, η2 = .62, such that need satisfaction was higher following inclusion (M = 4.67, SD = 0.99) than following exclusion (M = 2.54, SD = 0.74). Moreover, it yielded a significant interaction effect, F(1, 128) = 8.03, p = .005, η2 = .06 (see also Table 1). Simple effects analysis revealed that exclusion did not reduce need satisfaction relative to inclusion as strongly in claimball, F(1, 128) = 69.86, p < .001, η2 = .35, as in classic cyberball, F(1, 128) = 145.77, p < .001, η2 = .53 (see Figure 1). Moreover, need satisfaction differed significantly between games following inclusion, F(1, 128) = 10.23, p = .002, η2 = .07, but not following exclusion, F(1, 128) = 0.71, p = .400, η2 = .01. Thus, as predicted, exclusion was equally detrimental for fundamental needs when it was withheld or not claimed, but inclusion that was granted was more beneficial than inclusion that was claimed.2

fn.p: Note: Ratings were provided on a 7-point scale. Higher scores indicate higher need satisfaction. Note that means with different subscripts within the same row are significantly different at least at the p < .01 level.

caption.p: Mean level of fundamental needs reported in Study 1, as a function of inclusion or exclusion, and in either claimball or classic cyberball
Note: Standard errors are represented by the error bars attached to each column.

sec.p: To assess whether each need contributed to this effect, we also conducted separate analyses (see Table 1). Satisfaction of each of the needs was lower after exclusion than after inclusion in both games (all ps ≤ .009, η2s ≥ .05). Thus, as is typical for inclusion/exclusion manipulations using cyberball (K. D. Williams, 2007), being excluded versus included had a detrimental impact on all four fundamental needs. Moreover, this was true both in classic cyberball and in claimball. In addition, game experience and game type interacted in their effect on belonging, F(1, 128) = 13.67, p < .001, η2 = .10, and meaningful existence, F(1, 128) = 6.33, p = .013 η2 = .05, but not on control and self-esteem (ps ≥ .205, η2s ≤ .01). Moreover, belongingness and meaningful existence (ps ≤ .007, η2s ≥ .06) differed between games in the inclusion condition, but not in the exclusion condition (ps ≥ .273, η2s ≤ .01), whereas self-esteem and control did not differ across any of these conditions (ps ≥ .150, η2s ≤ .02). Stated differently, the differential impact of inclusion in classic cyberball and claimball was driven mainly by the need to belong and the need for meaningful existence.

sec.title: Study 2
sec.p: Study 1 provides first evidence for our reasoning. In Study 2, we extend this in several ways. First, we investigate why claimed inclusion fails to be as satisfying as inclusion that is granted by others. For this purpose, we draw on recent insights that inclusion is associated with warmth. For example, compared with exclusion, inclusion increases perceptions of room temperature and reduces people’s longing for warm food and drinks (Zhong & Leonardelli, 2008). We expect that the effect of inclusion on warmth will also depend on the antecedent process. As giving is more strongly associated with warmth than taking (L. E. Williams & Bargh, 2008), we predict that participants who are included in classic cyberball will think their interaction partners perceive them to be warmer than participants included in claimball.

Furthermore, we draw on a central notion in research on person perception that people’s main criterion to interpret, judge, and react to other people’s behavior is its warmth (Fiske, Cuddy, & Glick, 2006; Wojciszke, 2005). In line with this notion, we expect that people will react differently to inclusion depending on their perception of the level of warmth involved. Given that people prefer relationships marked by mutual affective concern (Baumeister & Leary, 1995), we expect that people will find inclusion in relationships more satisfying when their interaction partners perceive them to be warm. Thus, we expect that meta-perceptions of warmth will mediate the effect of the different conditions on need satisfaction. More specifically, we predict that participants who are included in claimball as opposed to classic cyberball will think their interaction partners feel less warmly toward them and as a result will experience lower levels of need satisfaction.

Second, we extend our findings from how people feel to how they behave toward others. That is, we assess whether others benefit or suffer depending on the antecedents of their interaction partners’ inclusion. For this purpose, we build on the presumed link between inclusion/exclusion and prosocial behavior that is central in theories on belonging (Baumeister & Leary, 1995), exclusion (Baumeister, Brewer, Tice, & Twenge, 2007), and ostracism (K. D. Williams, 2009). That is, we assess whether claiming and receiving inclusion differentially predict behavioral outcomes by measuring prosocial behavior in a dictator game (Forsythe, Horowitz, Savin, & Sefton, 1994).

We argue that meta-perceptions of warmth will also mediate the effect of claimed versus received inclusion on prosocial behavior. Again, we predict that participants who are included in classic cyberball will think their interaction partners perceive them to be warmer than participants included in claimball. Moreover, as friendly behavior tends to be reciprocated (Byrne & Rhamey, 1965; Sadler & Woody, 2003), and assuming that giving inclusion is a more friendly act than letting someone claim it, and that prosocial behavior is more friendly than antisocial behavior, we predict that people will behave more prosocially to their fellow players following inclusion in classic cyberball than following inclusion in claimball.

Finally, to ensure that the effect on need satisfaction and prosocial behavior do not simply result from changes to participants’ affective states, we tested whether mood acted as an alternative mediator.

sec.title: Participants and procedure
sec.p: Psychology undergraduates at Tilburg University (n = 113) took part. One participant was removed after playing the ballgame twice under different conditions, leaving 112 participants (71.4% female) ranging in age from 18 to 60 (M = 21.44, SD = 4.91). Apart from adding measures of mood, warmth, and prosocial behavior, the procedure was identical to that used in Study 1.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: To assess mood, participants indicated to what extent they experienced nine mood items during the game. Eight items were taken from the expanded Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (Watson & Clark, 1991): Two items each measured positive affect (“enthusiastic” and “proud”), guilt (“ashamed” and “unhappy with myself”), hostility (“irritated” and “angry”), and sadness (“sad” and “lonely”). A final item assessed hurt feelings (“hurt”), an emotion Smart Richman and Leary (2009) termed the signature emotion of rejection. The items were rated on 7-point bipolar scales ranging from 1 (not at all) to 7 (very much), reverse scored, and averaged to create a mood composite (α = .82).

To assess to what extent participants attributed their inclusion or exclusion in the game to other players’ perception of their warmth, we included three “warmth” items (i.e., “The other players thought I was well intentioned/warm/ good-natured”; based on Fiske, Cuddy, Glick, & Xu, 2002, Study 2). The items were rated on 7-point bipolar scales ranging from 1 (not at all) to 7 (very much) and averaged to create a warmth composite (α = .94).

To measure prosocial behavior, participants first divided 10 Euros between themselves and Player A in a dictator game (Forsythe et al., 1994), and then did the same for Player B. Both times, they were given the choice between five alternatives in which the other received, respectively, 2, 3, 4, 5, or 6 Euros (and they kept, respectively, 8, 7, 6, 5, or 4 Euros themselves). The amounts given to the two players were averaged to create a composite of prosocial behavior (α = .93).

sec.title: Manipulation checks
sec.p: The manipulations were successful. Excluded participants (M = 8.83, SD = 10.64) recalled receiving less ball tosses than included participants (M = 33.91, SD = 12.39), F(1, 83) = 98.57, p < .001, η2 = .54, and the vast majority of participants (96.59%) correctly stated whether they had to click to throw the ball or to claim the ball. Removing the participants who had incorrectly answered this question did not affect the results, and no other differences were significant.

sec.title: Need satisfaction
sec.p: Like in Study 1, we ran a 2 (game experience) × 2 (game type) ANOVA on the need composite (α = .97). This yielded a main effect of game experience, F(1, 108) = 199.34, p < .001, η2 = .65, such that need satisfaction was higher following inclusion (M = 5.06, SD = 1.18) than exclusion (M = 2.57, SD = 0.73), and a main effect of game type, F(1, 108) = 5.13, p = .025, η2 = .05, such that need satisfaction was higher following classic cyberball (M = 3.90, SD = 1.66) than following claimball (M = 3.72, SD = 1.51). Moreover, and most importantly, this again yielded a significant interaction effect, F(1, 108) = 7.93, p = .006, η2 = .07 (see Table 2 for descriptive statistics of all dependent variables). Simple effects analysis revealed that exclusion reduced need satisfaction relative to inclusion more strongly in classic cyberball, F(1, 108) = 151.64, p < .001, η2 = .58, than in claimball, F(1, 108) = 60.58, p < .001, η2 = .36. Moreover, need satisfaction differed between games following inclusion, F(1, 108) = 13.04, p < .001, η2 = .11, but not following exclusion, F(1, 108) = 0.15, p = .699, η2 < .01. Thus, replicating the results of Study 1, exclusion was equally detrimental for fundamental needs when it was withheld or not claimed, but granted inclusion was more beneficial than claimed inclusion.

fn.p: Note: Ratings were provided on a 7-point scale. Higher scores indicate higher need satisfaction. Note that means with different subscripts within the same row are significantly different at least at the p < .01 level.

sec.p: Again, separate Game experience × Game type ANOVAs followed by simple effects analysis revealed that satisfaction of each of the needs was lower after exclusion than after inclusion in both games (all ps ≤ .001, η2s ≥ .09). Thus, again being excluded versus included had a detrimental impact on all four fundamental needs in both games. Moreover, again game experience and game type mainly interacted in their effect on belongingness, F(1, 108) = 17.08, p < .001, η2 = .14, meaningful existence, F(1, 108) = 4.40, p = .038 η2 = .04, but not on self-esteem, F(1, 108) = 0.45, p = .504, η2 < .01. However, this time there was also a significant interaction effect on control, F(1, 108) = 4.01, p = .048 η2 = .04, and a main effect of game type on self-esteem, F(1, 108) = 8.60, p = .004, η2 = .07. Simple effects analyses revealed that none of the needs differed between games in the exclusion condition (all ps ≥ .400, η2 ≤ .01) but that belongingness, control, and meaningful existence (ps ≤ .013, η2s ≥ .06) differed significantly between games in the inclusion condition, whereas self-esteem (p = .203, η2s = .02) did not. Thus, again, similar to Study 1, the differential impact of inclusion in classic cyberball and claimball was primarily driven by belonging and meaningful existence. However, adding to Study 1, this time it was also driven by control.

sec.title: Prosocial behavior
sec.p: The 2 × 2 ANOVA on prosocial behavior also revealed a significant main effects of game experience, F(1, 108) = 48.33, p < .001, η2 = .31, such that prosocial behavior was higher following inclusion (M = 3.87, SD = 1.13) than following exclusion (M = 2.54, SD = 0.91), and a significant interaction effect between game experience and game type, F(1, 108) = 10.09, p = .002, η2 = .09. Again, there was a higher effect of game experience in classic cyberball, F(1, 108) = 54.23, p < .001, η2 = .33, than claimball, F(1, 108) = 6.76, p = .011, η2 = .06, and a significant effect of game type in the inclusion, F(1, 108) = 8.27, p = .005, η2 = .07, but not the exclusion condition, F(1, 108) = 2.63, p = .108, η2 = .02. Thus, prosocial behavior reflected the predicted pattern.

sec.title: Warmth
sec.p: Repeating the analysis with warmth as a dependent variable revealed a highly similar pattern: a significant main effect of game experience, F(1, 108) = 53.41, p < .001, η2 = .33, such that warmth was higher following inclusion (M = 4.37, SD = 1.33) than exclusion (M = 2.77, SD = 1.17); a significant main effect of game type, F(1, 108) = 5.02, p = .027, η2 = .04, such that warmth was higher following classic cyberball (M = 3.73, SD = 1.66) than following claimball (M = 3.38, SD = 1.24); and a significant interaction effect between game experience and game type, F(1, 108) = 16.80, p < .001, η2 = .14. Moreover, again there was a higher effect of game experience in classic cyberball, F(1, 108) = 68.81, p < .001, η2 = .39, than claimball, F(1, 108) = 4.88, p = .029, η2 = .04, and a significant effect of game type in the inclusion condition, F(1, 108) = 20.29, p < .001, η2 = .16, but not the exclusion condition, F(1, 108) = 1.71, p = .194, η2 = .02. Thus, the games affected perceived warmth in the predicted manner.

sec.title: Mood
sec.p: Running the same ANOVA on mood revealed a main effect of game experience such that participants’ mood was better following inclusion (M = 5.50, SD = 0.75) than following exclusion (M = 4.19, SD = 0.92), F(1, 108) = 72.18, p < .001, η2 = .40. Moreover, there was a main effect of game type such that participants’ mood was better following classic cyberball (M = 4.95, SD = 1.09) than following claimball (M = 4.74, SD = 1.03), F(1, 108) = 4.26, p = .041, η2 = .04. However, the interaction effect was not significant (F < 1).3

sec.title: Mediation
sec.p: To test whether warmth mediated the effects of game experience and game type on need satisfaction (see Table 3 for detailed results), we followed the three-part procedure outlined by Baron and Kenny (1986). First, we regressed game type and game experience on need satisfaction, adding their interaction term in a second step. This yielded a significant interaction effect. Second, we did the same for warmth, yielding again the significant interaction. Finally, we assessed the simultaneous effect of the games and of warmth on need satisfaction. The interaction term no longer predicted need satisfaction, but the effect of warmth remained significant. Moreover, a Sobel test indicated that the mediation was significant. Thus, the conditions for mediation were met.

fn.p: Note: Sobel tests of mediation were significant for both need satisfaction (z = 3.55, p < .001) and prosocial behavior (z = 2.93, p = .003).

fn.label: a
fn.p: Independent variables game experience, game type, Game experience × Game type.

sec.p: To test whether warmth also mediated the effects of game experience and game type on prosocial behavior, we repeated the procedure with prosocial behavior as a dependent variable. Again, this pattern of results meets the criteria for mediation. To check whether mood is also a viable mediator, we reran all regressions with mood. Although mood was related to need satisfaction (βstandardized = .817, p < .001) and prosocial behavior (βstandardized = .459, p < .001), the interaction effect of game experience and game type on need satisfaction (βstandardized = .139, p = .001; z = 0.49, p = .622) and prosocial behavior (βstandardized = .238, p = .002; Sobel test: z = 0.47, p = .635) remained significant. Hence, mood did not mediate our effects.

sec.title: General Discussion
sec.p: Humans are social animals (Aronson, 1994) that generally require a certain level of inclusion in groups and relationships to remain physically and psychologically healthy (Baumeister & Leary, 1995). We assessed the effect of two antecedents, one’s own actions or those of others, on the immediate experience of two inclusionary states, inclusion or exclusion in a group. Across two experiments, how people ended up excluded did not make a difference. The immediate impact of exclusion was equally detrimental for people’s fundamental needs, warmth, and prosocial behavior, regardless of whether the ball was not thrown to them or failed to be claimed by them. In contrast, how people ended up included did make a difference. When people managed to claim a ball as often as other players, their fundamental needs were less satisfied and they gave less to interaction partners than when they were thrown the ball as often as other players. Moreover, they thought others perceived them to be less warm, and this relative lack of warmth satisfied their fundamental needs to a lesser extent and made them less inclined to behave prosocially to interaction partners. These results imply that the immediate impact of claiming rather than receiving inclusion is to significantly undermine its psychological and interpersonal benefits.

Our findings make several contributions to theorizing on belongingness (Baumeister & Leary, 1995), exclusion (Baumeister et al., 2007), and ostracism (K. D. Williams, 2009). Importantly, we provide evidence that the immediate impact of processes underlying inclusion and exclusion need not work in similar ways on the two ends of the inclusionary continuum. We concur that people’s immediate reaction to exclusion are negative and undifferentiated (K. D. Williams, 2009). Prior research found that people are instantly hurt by exclusion regardless of their disposition (Zadro, Boland, & Richardson, 2006), social categorization of interaction partners (Gonsalkorale & Williams, 2007; Smith & Williams, 2004; K. D. Williams et al., 2000; Zadro et al., 2004), and even when they are financially compensated (Van Beest & Williams, 2006). We add that excluded people are equally hurt when it results from a failure to claim inclusion as when it results from being denied inclusion. However, we show that people’s immediate reaction to inclusion differs depending on whether people claim it or whether it is granted to them. Thus, one needs to assess reactions to both inclusion and exclusion to fully understand the immediate effects of the processes underlying inclusionary states as they do not always work in similar ways on the two ends of the inclusionary continuum (Blackhart et al., 2009).

Moreover, we found that inclusion needs to be accompanied by perceptions of warmth to have a strong effect on well-being. This important finding is in line with the notion that both repeated interactions and interpersonal warmth are required to satisfy the need to belong (Baumeister & Leary, 1995). Moreover, it sheds light on prior research that failed to moderate how people experience inclusion. For example, when people were intentionally included by another person in an interaction, they most likely assumed that the person felt warmly toward them notwithstanding the university they attended (K. D. Williams et al., 2002), their smoking habit (Smith & Williams, 2004), the ideology they supported (Gonsalkorale & Williams, 2007), or the financial cost they incurred as a result of being included (Van Beest & Williams, 2006). However, people who were merely included as a result of a scripted procedure need not have assumed their interaction partner felt warmly about them, which may explain why prescripted inclusion was found to be less satisfying (Zadro et al., 2004). Thus, we argue that prior research found that inclusion had similar psychological consequences under a wide range of conditions because these conditions did not differ in terms of warmth. As this prior research did not measure the effect on warmth of the manipulations used, these claims are necessarily speculative and will need to be substantiated by future studies.

sec.title: Limitation and Future Research
sec.p: We observed that exclusion was worse than inclusion on all our indices of well-being. Moreover, we observed that inclusion resulting from the actions of others had a more positive effect on overall well-being than inclusion resulting from one’s own actions, whereas these antecedent processes did not affect the effect of exclusion on overall well-being. Thus, we found support for the predicted interaction between level of inclusion and antecedent process on the overall index of well-being. However, this predicted interaction was only significant for the need for belonging, meaning, and control. We do not know why this finding did not generalize across all four fundamental needs. Possibly, claiming inclusion did not reduce self-esteem relative to being given inclusion because self-esteem depends on feeling likeable as well as competent (Tafarodi & Swann, 2001). Thus, it is possible that claiming and receiving inclusion each boosted positive self-feelings in a different domain. More importantly, analyses of the separate needs showed that our findings are mostly based on changes in belonging and meaning. This underscores our reasoning that belonging remains a key motivation for people regardless of whether inclusion is largely the result of their own actions or others’ actions. Indeed, although we observed that inclusion that is claimed is less satisfying for belonging than inclusion that is granted, it remained more satisfying than being excluded. Hence, our results speak against the possibility that people simply do not care about belonging when it results from their own actions.

In that regard, it is even more striking that we observed our findings in a relatively neutral setting. After all, we did not manipulate the value of the group in either classic cyberball or in claimball. Thus, we do not know whether people were highly motivated to belong to the group while playing the game. Although these questions are beyond the scope of our current focus on the consequences of claiming or being granted inclusion, they may offer a fruitful path for further investigations. Given that previous research found that exclusion by undesirable group members is no less painful than exclusion by desirable ones (e.g., Zadro et al., 2004), we do not expect the value of the group to interact with the source (i.e., the self or others) of the exclusion. However, we do expect the value of the group to interact with the source of inclusion. The importance of interpersonal warmth for our findings suggests that the differential effects of claimed and received inclusion may depend on the value of the group. Participants may feel more warmly toward members of valued groups and thus react especially strongly to inclusion by interaction partners belonging to valued groups.

Our research distinguished between inclusion and exclusion resulting largely from one’s own actions or from those of others. Although beyond the scope of the current research, we note that participants in our studies may not necessarily have attributed their success or failure at attaining inclusion in line with the actions causing it. For example, because attributions tend to be self-serving (Mezulis, Abramson, Hyde, & Hankin, 2004), excluded participants may have attributed their exclusion to others regardless of game (e.g., “they collaborated so that I would not be able to claim the ball” in claimball), whereas included participants may have attributed their inclusion to themselves regardless of game (e.g., “I demonstrated that I deserved to be thrown the ball” in classic cyberball). Investigating the nature of people’s attributions of inclusion and exclusion, as well as their effect on people’s subsequent behavior, offers an interesting path for future research.

Although we limited ourselves to comparing immediate reactions to inclusion and exclusion when they resulted from different sources, future research might also compare longer term reactions across these conditions. In particular, we draw attention to the work of Molden, Lucas, Gardner, Dean, and Knowles (2009). They compared situations in which people were passively ignored by others with situations in which people were actively rejected by others. They argued that people who were ignored should experience a failure to gain social connection, whereas people who were rejected should experience a loss of social connection. The experiences of failing to claim inclusion and being denied inclusion might differ in a similar fashion. Participants in claimball need to claim the ball to be included in the game. Thus, if they end up excluded, this ostensibly happens after they have attempted to claim the ball and failed. Consequently, they might primarily experience this as a failure at gaining inclusion rather than a loss of inclusion. Thus, extrapolating from the findings of Molden and colleagues, they may be inclined to seek reengagement, which might also lead them to behave relatively prosocially. In contrast, participants in classic cyberball need to receive the ball from other players to be included in the game. As we expect that people will expect to be thrown approximately an equal proportion of the balls, we think that when this does not happen they will experience this as a loss of inclusion more than a failure to gain inclusion. Again extrapolating from the findings of Molden and colleagues, this experience of exclusion should make them relatively more inclined to withdraw from the interaction, which might also lead them to behave relatively less prosocially.

We investigated the mediating role of meta-perceptions of warmth (i.e., feeling perceived as well intentioned, warm, good natured) because of its implications for theorizing that both frequent interactions and a relationship marked by affective concern are required to satisfy the need to belong (Baumeister & Leary, 1995). Given that warm feelings and affective concern tend to go hand in hand, our findings generally supported this theoretical view. However, this does not mean that other variables might not also mediate the effect of inclusion on need satisfaction and prosocial behavior. For example, participants in classic cyberball may infer that their interaction partners choose to include them because they ascribed positive qualities to them other than warmth (e.g., trustworthiness, cooperativeness, or competence) or might attribute equally favorable qualities to their interaction partners. Such variables might also mediate the effects of inclusion on need satisfaction and prosocial behavior, particularly in situations in which such positive qualities are valued. Assessing whether and when such differences occur may be a fruitful path for future research.

Finally, our studies were also limited to the two types of game experiences (inclusion and exclusion) that were the focus of this research. Future studies might also assess the effects of over-inclusion, or appropriating a disproportionate number of ball throws. This may result in more than a simple extrapolation of the current findings. It is likely that claiming over-inclusion will be associated with less warmth than receiving it and, as a result, negatively impact well-being. However, claiming over-inclusion might also have a positive effect on other important dimensions of social perception, like competence (Fiske et al., 2006; Wojciszke, 2005), which may increase well-being. After all, being highly successful at claiming inclusion may make people feel victorious. Whether such an effect of competence on well-being will overrule our finding that warmth is essential for well-being remains an empirical question.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The broad implication of our results is that the lack of warmth associated with claimed inclusion as opposed to received inclusion reduces its psychological and interpersonal benefits. Thus, warmth is an indispensable part of belonging, suggesting that belongingness needs are only met if interactions are marked by a certain level of affectionate concern (Baumeister & Leary, 1995). Sadly, the people who crave belonging the most will be the most strongly motivated to try and increase it (Baumeister & Leary, 1995) and thus the most likely to revert to efforts to claim inclusion. Paradoxically, inclusion that people so effortfully try to secure for themselves may never quite be as satisfying or lead to equally prosocial behavior as inclusion that they effortlessly receive. To have its full impact, it seems, inclusion needs to be given.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

As participants compete for inclusion in claimball, one might argue that when one succeeds at being included, this is because the other players were unsuccessful and vice versa. Notwithstanding, one’s own behavior remains more a reason for inclusion or exclusion than in classic cyberball.

To check whether engagement in the game moderated these effects, we included the composite score as a covariate in the 2 × 2 ANOVA on fundamental needs. The main effect of game type remained nonsignificant, F(1, 127) = 2.55, p < .113, and the main effect of game condition remained significant, F(1, 127) = 197.52, p < .001, as did the interaction between game type and game condition, F(1, 127) = 7.76, p = .006. Moreover, there was no significant effect of engagement, F(1, 127) < 0.01, p < .973, on the fundamental needs composite. Thus, engagement did not moderate the effect of game type and game condition on fundamental needs, and does not offer an alternative explanation for our results.

Although our analysis yielded only main effects on the mood composite, one might wonder whether exclusion from claimball exacerbates specific types of mood, in particular feelings of hostility or guilt. To test this, we reran the ANOVA with each of these subscales as dependent variable. For guilt, this only yielded a main effect for game condition, F(1, 109) = 14.53, p < .001, such that guilt was higher when participants were excluded (M = 2.62, SD = 1.22) than when they were included (M = 1.81, SD = 1.07). No other effects were significant (ps ≥ .223). For hostility, this yielded both a main effect of game condition, F(1, 109) = 10.16, p = .002, such that hostility was higher when participants were excluded (M = 3.54, SD = 1.51) than when they were included (M = 2.80, SD = 1.22), and a main effect of game type, F(1, 109) = 10.16, p = .002, such that hostility was higher in claimball (M = 3.44, SD = 1.50) than in classic cyberball (M = 2.92, SD = 1.29). However, again the interaction was not significant (p = .268).
